task.title: Creating a Basic Elastic Load Balancing Configuration
task.shortdesc: Elastic load balancing requires two basic elements to function properly: a load balancer and instances registered with that load balancer. The following examples show how to set up the basic elements of an elastic load balancer configuraton.

task.title: Create a Load Balancer
task.shortdesc: The load balancer manages incoming traffic, and monitors the health of your instances. The load balancer ensures that traffic is only sent to healthy instances.

info.p: If you are running your load balancer in a virtual private cloud (VPC), you must specify subnets the load balancer should run in (using --subnets ) and the region or user to use to connect to the service. You can specify that the load balancer is private to the VPC (using --scheme internal). You can also specify security groups to assign to the new load balancer (using --security-groups).

If you are not running your load balancer in a VPC, you must specify availability zones the load balancer should run in (using --availability-zones ), as well as the endpoint URL for the load balancing service (using --url).
Optional arguments are marked below in italics.
info.codeblock: eulb-create-lb (--subnets SUBNET1,... | --availability-zones ZONE1,...) \ (--region USER@REGION | --url URL) \ --listener "lb-port=PORT, protocol={HTTP,HTTPS,SSL,TCP}, \ instance-port=PORT, \ instance-protocol={HTTP,HTTPS,SSL,TCP}, cert-id=ARN" \ --scheme internal \ --security-groups GROUP1,GROUP2 \ MyLoadBalancer

task.title: Register instances with the Load Balancer
task.shortdesc: The load balancer monitors the health of registered instances, and balances incoming traffic across the healthy instances.

taskbody.context: To register an instance with the load balancer:

info.codeblock: eulb-register-instances-with-lb --instances INSTANCE1,INSTANCE2,... \ (--region USER@REGION | --url URL) \ --access-key-id KEY_ID --secret-key KEY \ MyLoadBalancer

taskbody.result: Once you've created the load balancer and registered your instances with it, the load balancer will automatically route traffic from its endpoint URL to healthy instances.
